Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2013 02:19PM aviva5675 wrote: I took stuff to the hospital like my tablet, and never used them. Didnt bother with slippers, wore the socks they give you. -- by the second day my hair was gross, I jokingly asked nurse if there was something they could do--- she brought a shower-cap-hair-washer---what a marvelous invention. Put it on my head, massaged for a few minutes-took it off, my hair was wet and clean. Brilliant!!! Have a small pillow or sweatshirty thing to hold to your chest on ride home. To cushion the shoulder seat belt. or, I rode in the back, with lap belt. Have things on counter at home- you wont be able to reach up. Have bottles open, etc, or hopefully a helper for a few days to reach and do things for you. You wont be able to lift even a coffee mug, let alone a full one, for a bit. Have paper cups or I used a light weight rubbery commuter mug for awhile. Have your helper help you up from bed-- put their arm behind your back and shoulders and lift you up, then you can swing legs over and get out of bed. Fill your pain prescription beforehand. Youll want it when you get home. Ask about any arm excercises you can start doing and when. Ask nurse how to strip your drains. Take colace or miralax stuff even a few days prior-- all the pain meds will make you really constipated. Read the threads about getting ready for surgery. Have button front shirts to wear for first few weeks. If you cannot shower til drains are out, have a plan for washing up- maybe get a type of wipe or butt washer cloth thing to be able to wash with. Your helper will probably have to help you at least for a few days. Ask the dr or- I ended up putting some gauze pads taped over where the drain tubes exited my body. Dabbed a bit of neosporin there also. Felt more comfortable even psychologically, having that area covered and not against my shirt. Also pinned it (around the tube), a few inches down from there to my shirt, and then put the bulbs in the drain belt pockets...so they were dragging least possible.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 02:41PM aviva5675 wrote: gtgirl, there are a few excellent threads on surgery, before during and after, and things to take to hospital-- very helpful and full of information. I guess (mine was Aug 23), big button down shirts to wear for awhile, drain belt for the drains, or something so you can pin them up so they dont drag or get caught. Have your helper person the first few days help lift you up out of bed or chair by placing hands on back and pushing/lifting, will make getting up much easier. Put things youll need on the counters - you wont be able to lift your arms much or pull. Couldnt open the fridge, reach up to the micro, even lift a coffee mug-- so having things counter height helped. Paper or light weight rubber mugs for coffee/tea...Some surgeons let you shower and some dont til drains are out. Just a heads up- you might be sponge bathing for awhile! And my favorite: in the hospital day 2 my hair was so icky, I jokingly asked the nurse if there was something they could do, she said sure thing! and got this thing-- its basically a shower cap, she put it on, massaged my head a few minutes, took off and voila! my hair was clean and nice. Its somehow contained in the cap. Brilliant. So if you are in a few days or for at home ( I think even Walgreens has them) and want clean hair, try it.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 02:36PM aviva5675 wrote: I had 2 drains, came out different times, so each was pulled individually. I read at least once where the surgeon took one side and nurse the other and did both at once. The first one I was yapping away and didnt even realize it had been removed! I had to be less than 30cc draining for at least 24 hours before he would remove. No showering at all till both were out ( 2 1/2 weeks for me). I did not have a catheter. It was never mentioned. I did pee a few times in pre op, but theyre pushing fluids during that time as well. I tolerated anasthesia second time better than first, and am trying to get that 2d anas. dr for my exchange surgery in Jan. I was surprised about the lifting- I definitely couldnt lift a mug- first many days I used paper cups and a light rubber travel mug for hot. Couldnt cut/chop. Couldnt raise arms to my micro, let alone pull open the door. Couldnt open the fridge first few days. Pan of soup- well, you can probably put the pan on, can probably put the soup in- how will you get can open? Id say opener is out and so is pull top. Then trying to pour pot out, might be tough. Definitely try to have someone or a rotation of someones at least the first few days. Have them help you get up especially out of bed by lifting/raising you from your back. I slept in bed at night, during day rested on a couch, could push myself up better with legs from there. But all those things get easier after about a week, some faster than others, and Im sure we each recover at different rates.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2013 02:21PM aviva5675 wrote: Someone on Nov thread asked about getting ready..here are some thoughts, hope it helps: I took stuff to the hospital like my tablet, and never used them. Didnt bother with slippers, wore the socks they give you. -- by the second day my hair was gross, I jokingly asked nurse if there was something they could do--- she brought a shower-cap-hair-washer---what a marvelous invention. Put it on my head, massaged for a few minutes-took it off, my hair was wet and clean. Brilliant!!! Have a small pillow or sweatshirty thing to hold to your chest on ride home. To cushion the shoulder seat belt. or, I rode in the back, with lap belt. Have things on counter at home- you wont be able to reach up. Have bottles open, etc, or hopefully a helper for a few days to reach and do things for you. You wont be able to lift even a coffee mug, let alone a full one, for a bit. Have paper cups or I used a light weight rubbery commuter mug for awhile. Have your helper help you up from bed-- put their arm behind your back and shoulders and lift you up, then you can swing legs over and get out of bed. Fill your pain prescription beforehand. Youll want it when you get home. Ask about any arm excercises you can start doing and when. Ask nurse how to strip your drains. Take colace or miralax stuff even a few days prior-- all the pain meds will make you really constipated. Read the threads about getting ready for surgery. Have button front shirts to wear for first few weeks. If you cannot shower til drains are out, have a plan for washing up- maybe get a type of wipe or butt washer cloth thing to be able to wash with. Your helper will probably have to help you at least for a few days. Ask the dr or- I ended up putting some gauze pads taped over where the drain tubes exited my body. Dabbed a bit of neosporin there also. Felt more comfortable even psychologically, having that area covered and not against my shirt. Also pinned it (around the tube), a few inches down from there to my shirt, and then put the bulbs in the drain belt pockets...so they were dragging least possible.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2013 01:55PM aviva5675 wrote: Had my first MO follow up visit today. SAw him first 3 months ago. Actually saw a pa today, which I was skeptical about when I heard, but I ended up liking her a lot, and she was able to answer all my questions. Said all is doing well, if I havent had much se from the anastrazole then I probably wont have much in the future. Ill wait and see, as I know many women start se even after a year or two. She reiterated my low chances of recurrence, if im on the ai for 5 years, and also since my onco score was a 2. We discussed hot flashes. I said I think the zoloft (actually generic, sertraline) is now working as most flashes stopped about 2 weeks ago. She is having me start 400iu (?) of vitamin E twice a day to help with that. She said no they dont do further blood work or testing as a baseline other than the dexa scan. She did have me start 500mg of calcium x2 a day tho. Said its good for all women anyway. So things are good. I go back in 3 months and see the actual MO . I guess they switch off. Nothing to do but be watchful for abnormalities in skin, bone pain, persistent cough or abdominal pain. Things that could signal recurrence. So all in all, went well!

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 03:36PM aviva5675 wrote: Long day today...PS check up- he surprised me with wanting to do a first fill today, 4 weeks after the surgery.  Put 50cc on the right side, which is starting out smaller (both have te). Said that side will have a larger implant in the end also. Was pretty nervous, his partner used the 'stud finder' to find the ports, then they came at me with the cartoon huge size syringe and needle. I didnt look, and it wasnt too terrible. Mostly the pinch of the needle.  No pain from it- but its only the first fill.  Now weekly til I cry uncle. Then this afternoon off to PT.  Its pt for range of motion but also some study or probgram about lymphedema- I only had 2 nodes and 6 nodes removed, so not alot of worry. But she counseled me on stuff to watch for and did measurements. Then did range of motion movements and tested me. Im not toooooo bad tho she did find minor cording on right side, which I was suprised. She seems pretty confident that will clear. So excercises at home and more appts in next few weeks. Tired now!  Going to make a floor size calendar to start keeping all the different appts apart. Bone density test tomorrow morning.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 11:01AM aviva5675 wrote: Hi Kristy, welcome to the lumpy lounge, not good reason to have to meet people but everyone is very supportive and open. I am newly on this journey as well- diagnosed month ago with DCIS , had lumpectomy last Tuesday, with reconstruction at that time (rearranging everything after he took out the tissue, and fixing it up nice) with reduction on the left side at the same time to match everything up. I was nervous about the wire guided thing too- but it was easier putting it in than I expected.  Probably the worst part was the little needle stick when they numbed it up!  I didnt feel anything after that, and it was pretty fast. Yes it was weird looking at the little wire sticking out but they wrapped it up (huge!) right away and put the gown back up, and I never felt a thing after that. The surgery was good too, recovery room took awhile.  Took the vicodin that night and motrins after that for maybe 2 days, twice a day and no pain pills since.  No drains, yeah!  Went back after two days to PS office and he  unwrapped me and there they were. A week after and I feel good.  I have to say read up on the boards there are good suggestions for post surgery. One thing I did , ok two , is got front closing shirts to wear, and used an old soft tshirt of hubbies underneath, to pad the scar. But not sure you will be having that if its lumpectomy only. Good luck! Hope results are good for you and this will be behind you!!  I had less good news and more surgery now coming Friday (dmx with reconstruction)...Im in your shoes now- scared and wondering how that one will go.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 08:32AM aviva5675 wrote: Got home yesterday after bmx with expanders Friday afternoon. It all went better than I expected. Had to get to hospital, numbing cream for the snb dye- that was hard- 2 shots per side for the dye- on each breast Im numb from original surgery 2 weeks ago so didnt feel it. Other side tho was painful for 10 seconds. Then they had to redo right side, 2 more shots! Was at nuc med for 1 1/2 hrs.  Got back and it was time for surgery. Coming out of anasthes was better this time than before. Got up to room around 8pm, thank goodness for morphine button~ By the time nurses were done, tried to eat some soup, was midnight. Tried to sleep. Up all night but dozing at same time, odd feeling. Up and to bathroom about 6am. Was surprised I could do that~ So the day went well...walked a bit, sat up. Tried to eat. Second day better- tried to stay off morphine, went on Norco. Like I said , got home 230- napped. It was a long night last night- trying to find right position in bed-- it took about 3 times of rearranging all the pillows but finally got it ok. Norco every 4 hours. great hubby set his phone alarm and kept waking me up.  At hospital the breast care center gave this big bag of stuff including a zip up cami-  the ps took off the compression wrap at hospital said I dont need it if I dont want...went with the cami- but the seams were painful.  Ended up putting some gauze pads over the seams and unzipping it most of the way. The drain tubes are pinned to it, but its not compressing the surgery area. Was a bit surpised he was fine with nothing comprssing, but he was just 'be normal' with things... Drains are fine.  A bit painful on my sides, but easy to wear ( I have 2), and not draining much. Hopefully at least one out when I see him tomorrow. HOpe this is good for those upcoming with surgeries- it will be ok!!

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2013 07:50AM aviva5675 wrote: MY PT is a cert LE specialist. Ive gone 3 times. The first time she measured me all over the arms for the LE tracking and talked about ways to avoid it. She did find minor cording in one area and helped me with that. By the 3d visit that was gone. She did talk specifically about getting sleeves if I am going to fly. Otherwise the visits were for range of motion, which she measured my abilities each time, and did massage, gave me excercises to do and showed my scar massage. From the 2d to the 3d visit she said there was a big difference.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 12:59PM aviva5675 wrote: I can relate to this: had biopsy of 2 areas of right side, found a dcis one on spot. Planned for lumpectomy with oncoplasty and reduction on left side to match. Also did lx on the 2d/benign spot while they were in there. When they did the pathology of the tissue they found an invasive tumor where it was supposed to be a benign area AND a small invasive tumore by coincidence on the left side, looking thru tissue removed during the reduction. Hadnt even had a 2d look mammo for the left side. As Beesie says, its probably coincidental- but there they were. The right side invasive had been 'just missed' by the biopsy.  I went back 10 days later for double mastect.   They did sentinal node biopsy then- and fortunately all nodes were clear. So it is possible. Talk more to your BS. Possibly put off surgery til you have more info?  I personally wouldve had the double even if the left side tumor was not found- only the invasive on right- as I personally wouldnt want to go thru life waiting for the other shoe to potentially drop. But thats me.
Posts.Title: tumor in both breasts?? nursemom sept45

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2014 03:43PM aviva5675 wrote: I was in your boat as well. Went for regular mammo and got a call for a 2d look. Wasnt freaked cause its happened before. Then they want to biopsy 2 places where there are calcifications.  That was a bit freaky- they sent me to the breast center at the hospital. One was in an easy place, the other was harder. Make sure they give lots of nice medication to numb you.  I developed a bit of hematoma after , took few weeks to resolve but was ok.  Long story short, found a dcis. Went few weeks later for a lumpectomy, lift, with matching lift on other side. Wasnt terrible.  I was glad I did that because (and this is me- not what will happen to you!), found smaller invasives on both sides. One that the biopsy needle had just missed. Went back 10 days later for double mastectomy (bmx) with tissue expanders (te) for reconstruction. I too was freaked out, knew not what to ask, ets. Found this site and it helped tremendously. Stick to real sites like this or Mayo etc for info, to get real facts, not freaked out people screaming.  Your data can come back clear! But if not you are not on the journey alone. Many have walked before you and can help.  Lots of threads here full of good info. and be sure to read the actual fact articles on bc.org, full of info about each part of the disease and treatments.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 12:06AM aviva5675 wrote: I was in August but can echo alot of what was said: for my lumpectomy they did a wire guided one for a second area- lying still was hard, they numb the area, I didnt look but there it is sticking way out of you..its packed loosely but well and covered, never thought about it again, was fine.  They removed tissue in that area that the biopsy just missed and found a larger invasive tumor in addition to the dcis they went in for initially. I ended up bmx 10 days later. for that they did a snb, and I got the dye shots. That hurt a bit but only for about 10 seconds while it went in. Of the 4, 2 hurt since the other sides of my breast were numb from the previous surgery. So not fun, but couldve been worse. Was on norco and tylenol by day 3 and only took the norco at night few nights after that, only Tylenol in day. Im lucky and my te are ok, Im almost 4 weeks out and really no pain, have been gently side sleeping, and drove about 45 minutes today with minimal problem. Agreed also: keep things low. Get paper/light plastic cups for hot drinks, dont try to lift mugs. My microwave is high and couldnt reach it for a week. Couldnt open the back door. Get baby type wipes to help you wash. Hubby washed my hair in sink for 2 weeks. Have lots of various types of pillows to nest/prop you in bed or chair- I use one under each arm still, and you will be back sleeping for awhile, so find a way to get comfortable. I used one under my knees also for awhile, I stopped but might go back. They did that in hospital and it was comfortable and helped me like a wedge to lay back on the upright pillows.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 03:24PM aviva5675 wrote: Visiting from the August surgies thread- hang in there ladies! It does get better. Im a little more than 3 weeks out from bmx with TE put in. My surgery took about 3 hours. I had a 2x lumpectomy with reconstruction on right and reduction on left 10 days before that. Original dcis was removed, but then they found idc on both sides, so bmx on 8/23.  I was 2 days in hospital. Not a ton of pain, took Norco for a few nights, tylenol. Sleeping was hard, really nest yourself with pillows under both arms, youll be back sleeping for awhile. They have you up and walking even in hospital and I made it a point to walk even to the corner once I was home. Im up to 2 miles now at a time, and trying to slow jog.  Your arms if you have nodes out will have limited range of motion, that is normal, and some sensitivity on underneath arm (not armpits) area from nerve damage. Mine has cleared some but is still there.  After about a week I was much less fatigued. Going to do half days at work starting in a week.  So good luck! Itll be ok!  My te arent painful, just odd feeling....First fill will be in a few weeks.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2013 01:44PM aviva5675 wrote: 1- I had the node injections on either side of my nipples,not in them. I had the cream and it still hurt, but only while they were injecting. You have your arm above your head and the nurse gripped my hand and made me squeeze hard, that helped. But it wasnt fun. Once the shot if over there is no pains, so maybe 10 seconds per.  The whole radiology part did take awhile tho cause they have to wait for it to go where they want it to go so the scan can pick up the correct images. 2- I had bmx w/te. 5 weeks ago now. I was terrified of the te pain and problems.  Wasnt nearly what I thought. We do all have different reactions, so this is me.  The pain the first 24 hours after surgery was bad, yippee for morphine drip! After that I went to norco, used the morphine a bit that 2d night. Then norco only, 2 more days, if that, used only at night, tylenol during the day.  It was very difficult using/moving arms for awhile. Have things on the counter, paper hot cups- you wont want to try lifting a mug. Obviously if there is someone to help you at home, thats best. I back slept for a good 3 weeks before even trying to go to the side a little. A pillow between the te helps. Now I clutch a pillow, but can sleep on my side. I got 100cc during my surgery. Pillows all around are your best friend. I dont really feel my te. That will probably change as I get more fills, but for now in general I dont think much about them.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 05:29PM aviva5675 wrote: I had no drains for lx, or for the 2 exchange surgeries I had. 2 drains after bmx. One out after 5 days, one out after 2 1/2 weeks. Depends on how its draining. So there is no normal!! Each dr is different what his thresh hold is before will remove, mine was also 15 cc for 24 hrs. I used a drain belt- wide velcro that came with 4 drain pockets that velcro to the belt, kept them out of the way. I also used a safety pin around the tube, near the top where it exited the skin, and pinned to shirt up there-- helped at least psychologically to keep them from getting snagged. In terms of stripping the drains- I was never shown it, and didnt do it- but I have read on here that if you use a little alcohol pad to do it it slides down the tube easier.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 10:06PM aviva5675 wrote: 1-- it takes several weeks to start really feeling better after the surgery. Be patient, like others said, take the pain pills as needed. The numb weird tingly feeling under arm and in armpit should improve. Its because nerves were damaged taking the nodes. From what I understand it should clear up, probably, not alway, but might take even 6 months. Try to get to a PT especially a lymphedema specialist, who can assess you and help with range of motion. Mine said I had a bit of cording in the upper arm area, and after a few visits and doing her excercises at home, it has gone away. That kind of thing has a lot to do with you being determined to need chemo or not. And I suppose your own MO.
